results.notes:
Gregarious on decaying hardwood log. Unique is the small to medium size (about 2cm), lignicolous habit, and pure white stipe that is glabrous and twists upon drying. Pileipellis appears to be a simple cutis with encrusted hyphae. Spores about 6-9×3-4. Sterile edge with chains of cheilocystidia, the chains appear mostly repent and slightly gelatinized.

—

results.notes:
Collected by Al Trupio at the NJMA foray. It was one of very few amanita taxa picked at FREC and certainly the most interesting one.
Unfortunately, Al didn’t do a proper extraction of the base. In Al’s defense, looks like the stipe may have been deeply inserted into the ground, which explains why he had trouble with fishing it out whole. The cap was of this interesting brownish-yellow / goldenrod color (the camera made it more brown) and the lower stipe surface was decorated with these long blackish fibrils (the fibrils’ color is likely due to fine dirt adhering to them).
I thought this was an interesting find because I didn’t immediately recognize it as something I had already seen, and also on the account of the habitat (Pine Barrens) being populated with few known/recorded sect. Vaginatae (dulciarii group, fulva, jakeslandensis, pakimpondensis, sinicoflava, and williamsiae). Maybe it is a new species. This will be sequenced.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 14-May-21):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 610 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma and uploaded to this post. The full-length consensus nrITS sequence of two reads is 477 characters long (ITS1 = 173 bps, 5.8S = 160 bps, ITS2 = 144 bps). It’s flanked on its left by the last 46 nucleotides of nrSSU and by the first 87 bps of nrLSU on its right. There is a single ambiguous position, “R” (A/G), in the ITS1 region. This is a mainstream sect. Vaginata taxon because the first three characters of LSU are “TTT”, as opposed to “TCT” found in series Penetratrices (http://amanitaceae.org/?series%20Penetratrices).
> A BLASTn-100 search of the full-length ITS sequence gave no matches or close hits, meaning that this organism is only distantly related to anything published in GenBank. The highest % similarity achieved is only 91% with Amanita glarea, a species described from Pakistan. The E values for all hits are above zero.
> A BLASTn-100 of the ITS1 sublocus gave a different hit profile, though the overall result was the same, i.e. no perfect or close matches. When the hit list is sorted by Max/Total Score or % Query Cover, accessions of Amanita pakimpondensis nom. prov. (known only from NJ), are the top hits at only 90.5% similarity & 94% query cover. When sorted by % identity, accessions of Amanita pahasapaensis nom. prov. (known from AZ, NM & SD) are the top hit at 96% similarity but only 71% query cover. The E values for all hits are above zero.
> The standard BLASTn search of the ITS2 sequence really proves that this species is quite unique. Only 3 hits out of expected 100 were recovered in the 88.3-90.4% similarity range and 85% query cover! This means that the ITS2 region is so dissimilar from all sequences in the database that the software simply excluded them from being listed.
> A search of Rod Tulloss’ private sequence database apparently came back empty-handed, too. This means that we can give this critter a provisional name. I am proposing Amanita trupioi I. Safonov & Kudzma nom. prov. in honor of its discoverer, Al Trupio.

results.notes:
Fruiting in Spruce chips.
Caps: 6-18cm wide. Flat topped at maturity, covered in flocked reddish brown fibrils. Staining blue/green.
Stem: Somewhat purple toned in young specimens, mature specimens yellow with reddish striations(staining blue/green). See all images.
Mycelium:stains blue(see images).
Taste: bitter.
Spore Printed a single cap for microscopy.
Spore print: rusty orange brown.
Temp: has been upper 60’s/70’s last few weeks. No low temps caused bluing reactions in specimens.
Spores: ellipsoid but Irregular/angular on side laying individuals.
Harvested/dried multiple specimens for herbarium collection. Multiple images in thumbnail bar of aging process and deep blue/green staining of all specimens.
UPDATE: Mailed dried/bagged/labeled samples from this collection to 2 separate interested mycologists on 11/5/2020 for accession into their herbarium and sequencing dried material.

results.notes: My first encounter with this for the Netherlands rather rare taxon. Growing in a typical habitat: on a grassy roadside, about 1,5 meter from a busy crossover to the woods, thus a place where dogs and people disturb the soil frequently, making it a somewhat eutrophic habitat. Along with the remarkable bright white colour, the strong farinaceous odour, the fragility , and the presence of velum partiale remnants, makes it easy to identify in the field.

results.notes:
In needle duff near a small recently-planted white pine.
Spores 15-18 × 5.5-7.5, profile subfusoid to ellipsoid, depending upon alignment. Mounted in Meltzer’s some spores appear to be slightly dextrinoid. Champignons du Quebec says the spores of C. flavipes are 18-29 × 6-8.5. I wonder if this is a misprint?
I have never found the species Chroogomphus flavipes. At Ricketts Glen I have found what I IDed as C. vinicolor. The mushrooms seen here in this observation lack purplish/reddish coloration on the caps. The stipes are yellow with purplish overtones. Judging from appearance, these fruit bodies do not look like C. vinicolor.
KOH dark purple on cap surface; ammonia reddish-purple on cap surface.
results.location_name: Ricketts Glen State Park, Pennsylvania, USA

results.notes:
Growing from roots at base of living flamboyán trees (Delonix regia, Fabaceae) on side of highway. Laccate stipitate, pilei fusing into large basidiomes with multiple stipes in some cases. Largest specimen with fused pilei exceeding 60cm. Cuticle soft, collapsible, very easily depressed with fingernail. Saffron layer readily exposed when pileus surface is scratched. Cuticle weakly amyloid, cells subclavate. Spores about 9-10×6 with acute, obtuse, or truncate apex, acute apex fairly common. Dry basidiome very lightweight. (PR55)

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 150278073 on March 5, 2023.

results.notes: On old cement foundation in a semi-arid grassland setting. Thallus not evident. Apothecia crowded, up to 0.5mm, plane. Margin raised, somewhat beaded, yellowish and distinctly lighter than dark orange epruinose disk. Spores large, with narrow isthmus. Average size: 18.8×8.8×2.0 (n=4).
results.location_name: Cholame Valley, Monterey Co., California, USA

results.notes:
This collection is on HCL+ calcareous sandstone bedrock in a semi-arid grassland setting. Thallus is squamulose, variably slate to brownish, with a K+V cortex. Epinecral layer lacking to thinly present. Algal layer mostly even but with occasional breaks. Apothecia stipitate, small, with a brownish disk. Thalline margin reduced with a prominant proper margin. Average spore size: 14.5×8.1×3.4 (n=4).

Previously considered to be C. albovariegata but current thinking is these are all C. peliophylla. See other MO posts for these species.

results.notes:
Datos de Yopal, registrado en Bosque Seco Tropical (temporada de lluvia). Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, Precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio. con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas. (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017). Son comunes plantas representativas como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.

Hola, lo ideal es que sigas estas recomendaciones, para que los registros y las descripciones que hagas, te permitan determinar el ejemplar:

-Tomar fotografías de las diferentes estructuras del basidioma/ascoma/cuerpo fructifero/carpoforo/seta (por encima, por debajo y de perfil), su estipe, pileo y base, en el caso de retirar el ejemplar sin conocerlo, debes comprometerte a realizar una descripción detallada para aportar a su conocimiento y que no quede en una muestra arrancada, fotografiada y desechada. Además de retirarlo con sustrato para conocer otras características de la base del basidioma.

-Es importante que describas las dimensiones (altura y diametro), forma, consistencia, textura, color y olor. Recuerda que los ejemplares cambian bastante según su estado de desarrollo, así que es ideal familiarizarse con la zona y temporada en la que crecen, para hacer un seguimiento y logres observar la variabilidad fenotípica del basidioma o ascoma (cuerpo fructífero).

-Toma fotos del entorno y agrega datos del ecosistema (humedad, temperatura, altura, tipo de bosque, insectos asociados, etc).

-No olvides que la determinación de macromicetos es compleja y no se realiza únicamente con fotografías, esta tarea (a nivel de género y especie; en la mayoría) implica actividades de descripción morfológica externa e interna, reacciones químicas, microscopia y ADN.

This collection will be sequenced and compared with the data I am getting for additional vouchers in the “dulciarii-vulpecula” complex.

results.notes:
Cuticle cells clavate, very thick with stratified layers of wax, swelling at the apex to over 20 um diam in some cases. Lumen is reduced or obscured by wax. Basidiospores about 9-12(13)x7 with a truncate apex. Smooth chlamydospores present in context, about 9-13(14) diameter. Context cork colored, darker below, not completely homogenous with scattered resinous bands and a saffron layer below cuticle. Cuticle cells not or indistinctly amyloid. Cuticle somewhat brittle, not yielding that easily under finger pressure. Parts of context and hymenium sometimes present sparse yellow exudate. Dry basidiome somewhat heavy. (PR56)

Cobh, County Cork, Ireland

results.notes:
These were found by Shaun Shaun at the base of a burnt and dead standing pine, around 4,500-5,00 feet. They were described as heavy, and unfortunately we didn’t get a section.
The caps are yellow to yellow-brown, up to 15 cms., spherical first, later convex, cracked, with an acute incurved margin, at least on some.
The pores yellow to yellow-brown with a slight reddish tinge.
The stipe appears to be solid central or maybe off-center, can’t see.
The flesh appears to be yellow in pictures 4 & 5.
Color change unknown.
In 2 clusters or 4 o 5 each, at the base of a single dead pine, sandy soil, unclear if on the ground or on wood.
First time I took a look at these pictures I thought of Albatrellus ellisii, later, in a closer look at the cap surface, pores and general habitat, I believe it could be Buchwaldoboletus; now leaning towards B. sphaerocephalus or B. orovillus.
Until now this species has not been identified around here, but I believe it was another sight earlier this year on MO420630.
Anybody will concur or disagree with this tentative identification? Could it be something else?

results.notes:
Growing, perennially in some cases, from two different trees which are ‘ingrown’ and are generally fused together at the trunk. Majority and largest basidiome are growing from a ‘centennial tree’ or large diameter indet. angiosperm. Some also appear to be growing from a fairly old mango tree alongside the centennial tree. Context is dark brown, fairly homogenous with concentric growth rings and scattered resinous bands. Old basidiome has entire cuticle cells (perhaps consistent with Ryvarden’s diagnosis of G. oerstedii (Torres-Torres 2014) but the young basidiome I examined had typical protruberances. Chlamydospores present in context. Contextual skeletal hyphae very dark brown in KOH, nodulose where branching. Basidiospores large and broad, sometimes up to 10um diam. Largest specimen about 40 cm diameter! observation 442873 is a subsequent collection. (PR54)

—

results.notes:
Thallus orange, but very little, mostly apothecia ~0.2 – 0.6 mm diam, lecanorine, circular to angular (esp. when crowded), +/- flat, with thalline rim gen. flush, lighter orange than apothecia.

Proper exciple: Appears to be composed of elongate hyphae (especially apparent between the middle and the margin), hyphae seem to become more globose at the margins (I think they may be highly widened paraphyses tips (or whatever the paraphyses equivalent is for exciple).
Thalline exciple: full of algae, subtending or arriving even with proper exciple.
Paraphyses: widening at tips, unbranched. Epihymenium: dark orange. Hymenium: hyaline, ~70-80 um, possibly inspersed with tiny oil droplets, unsure). Subhymenium: hyaline, tough to distinguish boundary with exciple. Spores: 15.5 × 5.9 um, septum 3.6 um wide; 14.5 × 6.4, 2.2; 15.1 × 6.8, 2.4; 13.9 × 6.1 × 2.3 um. Spores: 8/ascus.

Cortex paraplectenchymatous, roughly 15-20 um thick above a continuous algal layer.

Keying notes: Using Nash 2007 I arrive at C. ludificans two separate ways. The characters and measurements all seem to line up. In the macro view, there appears to often be a lighter-colored thalline margin, though in section it looks like the proper margin is dominant. So, best guess is C. ludificans for now. At some point soon will compare with Observation 434687 and Observation 439055, which I tentatively ID’d as Polycauliona bolacina but was considering as Polycauliona ludificans as well.

results.notes: A nice group of still young pilei of this interesting species was growing under an old large mountain Picea abies. This is unusual since this species more frequently grows on broadleaved trees. The grown up pilei become much larger than those shown on these pictures. Pholiota squarrosa is quite a common mushroom here. Its determination is not difficult because of its typical habit and characteristic scales all over it. Yet, mistakes are not impossible since at least three other very similar species of this genus grow in Slovenia – Pholiota aurivella, Pholiota adiposa and Pholiota jahinii (Ref.1.) Pholiota aurivella grows on Salix and is only somewhat viscid or dry while Pholiota squarosa is always dry, without slime. Pholiota adiposa has a strongly glutinous, lustrous pileus with thin scales (Ref.:7) and Pholiota jahinii is also slimy and grows only on decayed broadleaved wood (Ref.:1).

results.notes:

Flesh: Red, somewhat transluscent. Very elastic, nearly impossible to tear by hand. Tastes moderately bitter.

Stipe: Length 3-7cm. Width 0.5-3cm. Straight, oval cross-section. Stuffed to hollow. Fibrous surface.

Gills: Dull pink. Adnexed (barely attached).

Spore print: white.

Ecology: Saprophytic on dead deciduous wood (probably beech). Gregarious to cespitose (small clusters).
